query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
1 In quella parte del giovanetto anno 2 che ’l sole i crin sotto l’Aquario tempra 3 e già le notti al mezzo dì sen vanno,
4 quando la brina in su la terra assempra 5 l’imagine di sua sorella bianca, 6 ma poco dura a la sua penna tempra,
7 lo villanello a cui la roba manca, 8 si leva, e guarda, e vede la campagna 9 biancheggiar tutta; ond’ ei si batte l’anca,
10 ritorna in casa, e qua e là si lagna, 11 come ’l tapin che non sa che si faccia; 12 poi riede, e la speranza ringavagna,
13 veggendo ’l mondo aver cangiata faccia 14 in poco d’ora, e prende suo vincastro 15 e fuor le pecorelle a pascer caccia.
query.result:
**English:**
1 In that part of the youthful year 2 when the sun tempers its rays under Aquarius 3 and the nights are already waning,
4 when the frost on the ground resembles 5 the image of its white sister, 6 but its pen does not last long,
7 the peasant, who lacks provisions, 8 gets up, looks out, and sees the countryside 9 all white; whereupon he beats his thigh,
10 returns home, and complains here and there, 11 like the wretch who does not know what to do; 12 then he goes out again, and hope revives,
13 seeing that the world has changed its face 14 in a short time, and he takes his crook 15 and drives his sheep out to pasture.
**Old English:**
1 On ðære tide ðæs geongan geares 2 ðe se sunne his loccas under Wætermanne tempreð 3 and ða niht alreaðe to midde-dæge wendon,
4 ðonne se rima ofer ða eorðan astemneð 5 ðære his sweostor hwitan ansyn, 6 ac lyt ðurh ðære penne tempre,
7 se ceorl ðe ðæs wæstmes gebrec, 8 arist, and lociað, and gesihð ða leah 9 ealle hwit; ðanon he hine sylfa sleað,
10 cyrreð to huse, and her and ðær ceariað, 11 swa se earming ðe ne wat hwæt he wyrce; 12 ðonne eft cymeð, and ða hyht regagneð,
13 geseonde ða woruld habban awende ansyn 14 on lytlum fæce, and nimð his gyrde 15 and ða sceap ut to wealdes drifeð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
22 Le braccia aperse, dopo alcun consiglio 23 eletto seco riguardando prima 24 ben la ruina, e diedemi di piglio.
query.result:
**English:**
22 His arms outstretched, after some counsel 23 taken with himself, first looking carefully 24 at the ruin, he seized me.
**Old English:**
22 His earmas tosperde, æfter sumum geþeahte, 23 geceosende him sylfum ærest 24 wel ða hryre, and geaf me his gripe.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
25 E come quei ch’adopera ed estima, 26 che sempre par che ’nnanzi si proveggia, 27 così, levando me sù ver’ la cima
28 d’un ronchione, avvisava un’altra scheggia 29 dicendo: «Sovra quella poi t’aggrappa; 30 ma tenta pria s’è tal ch’ella ti reggia».
query.result:
**English:**
25 And like one who works and estimates, 26 who always seems to be providing for the future, 27 so, raising myself up toward the top
28 of a large branch, I noticed another branch 29 saying: "Climb onto that one then; 30 but first test it to see if it will hold you."
**Old English:**
25 And swa swa se ðe wyrceð and penceð, 26 ðe symle ðinceð ðæt he ær gesceawige, 27 swa ic me sylfne on ða healfe ahof
28 ðæs hliðes, and ða geseah ic ðær ða oðre healfe 29 ðus cweðende: "Nu ðu ðær on stige; 30 ac fandia ær ðe ðu ðær on fare."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
31 Non era via da vestito di cappa, 32 ché noi a pena, ei lieve e io sospinto, 33 potavam sù montar di chiappa in chiappa.
query.result:
**English:**
31 It was not a path for one dressed in a robe, 32 for we, he lightly and I pushed forward, 33 could barely climb from crag to crag.
**Old English:**
31 Nis ðæt se weg ðe man sceal werian, 32 forðæm we, he anræd and ic ofsowie, 33 uneaðe míhton stigan and climban.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
34 E se non fosse che da quel precinto 35 più che da l’altro era la costa corta, 36 non so di lui, ma io sarei ben vinto.
query.result:
**English:**
34 And if it were not that from that boundary 35 the slope was shorter than on the other side, 36 I do not know about him, but I would have been utterly defeated.
**Old English:**
34 And gif hit nære ðæt ðæs stealles gesceaft 35 wæs from ðæm oðrum swiðor ascort, 36 ne can ic secgan, ac ic wiste þæt ic 37 wæs wædla and forwunded.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
37 Ma perché Malebolge inver’ la porta 38 del bassissimo pozzo tutta pende, 39 lo sito di ciascuna valle porta
40 che l’una costa surge e l’altra scende; 41 noi pur venimmo al fine in su la punta 42 onde l’ultima pietra si scoscende.
query.result:
**English:**
37 But because Malebolge hangs upside down 38 from the door of the lowest well, 39 the location of each valley causes
40 one side to rise and the other to descend; 41 we nevertheless came to the end at the point 42 where the last stone juts out.
**Old English:**
37 Ac forðæm þe Malebolge oninnanweard ðære dura 38 ðæs niðemestan pyttes ealles hangað, 39 ðæs setles stede ælces dales bereð
40 ðæt seo oðre healf astigeð and seo oðre healf astigeð; 41 we þeahhwæðere comon to ðæm ende on ðæm nosan 42 ðær ða ytemestan stan astigeð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
43 La lena m’era del polmon sì munta 44 quand’ io fui sù, ch’i’ non potea più oltre, 45 anzi m’assisi ne la prima giunta.
query.result:
**English:**
43 My breath was so exhausted in my lungs 44 when I was up that I could go no further, 45 but sat down where I first arrived.
**Old English:**
43 Þæs swæðul wæs me on ðam breostum swa gewæht, 44 ða ic up gewát, ðæt ic ne mihte furðor gán, 45 ac ic sæt me niðer on ðære forman stowe.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
52 E però leva sù; vinci l’ambascia 53 con l’animo che vince ogne battaglia, 54 se col suo grave corpo non s’accascia.
query.result:
**English:**
52 And therefore rise up; conquer your anguish 53 with the spirit that conquers every battle, 54 if it does not collapse with its heavy body.
**Old English:**
52 And forðæm arís; ofercumm ðíne earfoðu 53 mid ðæm mode ðe ofercýmeð ælce gewinn, 54 gif hit ne hrúsð mid hys hefigan líce.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
55 Più lunga scala convien che si saglia; 56 non basta da costoro esser partito. 57 Se tu mi ’ntendi, or fa sì che ti vaglia».
query.result:
**English:**
55 A longer stairway must be climbed; 56 it is not enough to have departed from these [spirits]. 57 If you understand me, now make it so that it benefits you.”
**Old English:**
55 Lengra stegere sceal mon stigan; 56 nis ðæt genoh ðæt ðu ðisne forlæte. 57 Gif ðu ðis andgitst, nu ðe selfum frem.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
58 Leva’mi allor, mostrandomi fornito 59 meglio di lena ch’i’ non mi sentia, 60 e dissi: «Va, ch’i’ son forte e ardito».
query.result:
**English:**
58 He lifted me up, showing himself 59 better supplied with strength than I felt myself to be, 60 and he said: "Go, for I am strong and bold."
**Old English:**
58 He ða up aras, and me mid handa 59 beteran ðonne ic wæs brohte ðurh ða burg, 60 and cwæð: "Nu ga, forðon ic eom fæst and gearo."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
61 Su per lo scoglio prendemmo la via, 62 ch’era ronchioso, stretto e malagevole, 63 ed erto più assai che quel di pria.
query.result:
**English:**
61 Up over the cliff we took our way, 62 which was rough, narrow, and difficult, 63 and steeper by far than the one before.
**Old English:**
61 Uppon ðone stan we ða stige fundon, 62 ðe wæs ruh and nearu and unlæde, 63 and steapre micle ðonne ða oðer wæs.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
64 Parlando andava per non parer fievole; 65 onde una voce uscì de l’altro fosso, 66 a parole formar disconvenevole.
query.result:
**English:**
64 He spoke so as not to seem feeble; 65 whereupon a voice came from the other ditch, 66 unsuited to forming words.
**Old English:**
64 Sprecende he ða ðurh ðæt he ne wolde ðæt he wære wafre; 65 ða com ðær ða stefn of ðam oðrum dic, 66 unlæde to ðam ðæt he wordum spræce.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
67 Non so che disse, ancor che sovra ’l dosso 68 fossi de l’arco già che varca quivi; 69 ma chi parlava ad ire parea mosso.
query.result:
**English:**
67 I do not know what he said, although I was already 68 on the other side of the stream that flows there; 69 but whoever was speaking seemed moved to anger.
**Old English:**
67 Ne ic nat ne can hwet he sæde, ðeah ðe ic ofer ðone beorg wære 68 ðæs burnan ðe ðær būð; 69 ac ða word ðe he spræc ðuhte ðe he on mode wearð yrre.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
70 Io era vòlto in giù, ma li occhi vivi 71 non poteano ire al fondo per lo scuro; 72 per ch’io: «Maestro, fa che tu arrivi
73 da l’altro cinghio e dismontiam lo muro; 74 ché, com’ i’ odo quinci e non intendo, 75 così giù veggio e neente affiguro».
query.result:
**English:**
70 I was turned downward, but my living eyes 71 could not reach the bottom because of the darkness; 72 therefore I said: "Master, make sure that you arrive
73 at the other bank and let us climb down the wall; 74 for, as I hear here and do not understand, 75 so I see below and can make out nothing."
**Old English:**
70 Ic wæs gewend niðer, ac ða lifigendan eagan 71 ne mihton faran to ðam grunde ðurh ðone deorcnesse; 72 for ðon ic cwæð: "Lareow, wyrc ðæt ðu cume
73 of ðam oðrum sidan and astige we ðone weall; 74 forðæm, swa swa ic gehýre her and ne ongyte, 75 swa ic geseo ðær neoðan and nawiht ne oncnáwe."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
76 «Altra risposta», disse, «non ti rendo 77 se non lo far; ché la dimanda onesta 78 si de’ seguir con l’opera tacendo».
query.result:
**English:**
76 "Another answer," he said, "I give you not, 77 except to do it; for the honest request 78 should be followed by the deed in silence."
**Old English:**
76 "Oðer andsware," cwæð he, "ne selle ic ðe, 77 buton ðæt ðu hit wyrce; forðæm ðe ðæt rihte bæn 78 man sceal mid ðæm weorce ðurhswugian."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
79 Noi discendemmo il ponte da la testa 80 dove s’aggiugne con l’ottava ripa, 81 e poi mi fu la bolgia manifesta:
82 e vidivi entro terribile stipa 83 di serpenti, e di sì diversa mena 84 che la memoria il sangue ancor mi scipa.
query.result:
**English:**
79 We descended the bridge from the head 80 where it joins with the eighth bank, 81 and then the pit was revealed to me:
82 and I saw within a horrible throng 83 of serpents, and of such diverse kinds 84 that the memory of it still chills my blood.
**Old English:**
79 We stigon of ðæm brycge ðær he hæfde heafod 80 ðær he gewunað ðæt he wunige 81 and ða wæs me ðæt stede swipe cuð:
82 and ic ðær geseah innan egeslicne heap 83 wyrma and næddra and ðara nædrena cyn 84 ðæt ðæs modes gemynd ða gyt mine blode cyleð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
85 Più non si vanti Libia con sua rena; 86 ché se chelidri, iaculi e faree 87 produce, e cencri con anfisibena,
88 né tante pestilenzie né sì ree 89 mostrò già mai con tutta l’Etïopia 90 né con ciò che di sopra al Mar Rosso èe.
query.result:
**English:**
85 Let Libya no longer boast of its sands; 86 for if it produces vipers, darts, and arrows, 87 and horned snakes with amphisbaenas,
88 never did Ethiopia, with all its plagues and evils, 89 or the region above the Red Sea, 90 display so many or such deadly ones.
**Old English:**
85 Ne mæg Libia mid hyre sande self giherian; 86 ðeah ðe heo wyrmas, wæpnedsperan and flanan 87 and næddran mid nædre gebringe,
88 ne onette næfre swylce wyrmcyn 89 mid ealle ðam attre ðe on Ethiopum is 90 and ðam ðe ofer Readan sæ ryneð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
91 Tra questa cruda e tristissima copia 92 corrëan genti nude e spaventate, 93 sanza sperar pertugio o elitropia:
94 con serpi le man dietro avean legate; 95 quelle ficcavan per le ren la coda 96 e ’l capo, ed eran dinanzi aggroppate.
query.result:
**English:**
91 Among this raw and most sorrowful company 92 ran naked and frightened people, 93 without hope of refuge or heliotrope:
94 their hands were tied behind them with snakes; 95 the snakes pierced their loins with their tails 96 and heads, and were knotted in front.
**Old English:**
91 Betwux ðissum reowan and ðam reowestan werode 92 urnon nacode and forhte men, 93 butan hyhtan holes oððe heolforwyrte:
94 mid næddrum wæron heora handa gebunden; 95 ða næddran sticodon heora lendenu mid ðam steortum 96 and ðam heafdum, and wæron beforan gecnæpte.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
97 Ed ecco a un ch’era da nostra proda, 98 s’avventò un serpente che ’l trafisse 99 là dove ’l collo a le spalle s’annoda.
query.result:
**English:**
97 And behold, a serpent darted at one who was on our side, 98 and pierced him where the neck joins the shoulders.
**Old English:**
97 And lo, a nædre ðe wæs on urum sidan, 98 ða wæs ðær an nædre ðe hine toslat, 99 ðær ðæs swuran and ðæs halses hi worþað an.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
112 E qual è quel che cade, e non sa como, 113 per forza di demon ch’a terra il tira, 114 o d’altra oppilazion che lega l’omo,
115 quando si leva, che ’ntorno si mira 116 tutto smarrito de la grande angoscia 117 ch’elli ha sofferta, e guardando sospira:
118 tal era ’l peccator levato poscia.
query.result:
**English:**
112 And just as someone who falls and does not know how, 113 through the force of a demon that drags him to the ground, 114 or some other impediment that binds a man,
115 when he gets up, looks around himself, 116 completely bewildered by the great anguish 117 that he has suffered, and sighs as he looks around:
118 such was the sinner, risen up afterwards.
**Old English:**
112 And swylce se ðe fylð and nat hû, 113 ðurh ðæs deofles strengðe ðe hine to eorðan teohð, 114 oððe ðurh oðre gehæftednysse ðe ðone man gebindað,
115 ðonne he arist, ðæt he hine ymbesihð 116 eal forhted fram ðære myclan angrysse 117 ðe he ðolode, and swegende bið:
118 swylc wæs se synfulla ða he ârâs.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
119 Oh potenza di Dio, quant’ è severa, 120 che cotai colpi per vendetta croscia!
121 Lo duca il domandò poi chi ello era; 122 per ch’ei rispuose: «Io piovvi di Toscana, 123 poco tempo è, in questa gola fiera.
query.result:
**English:**
119 Oh power of God, how severe it is, 120 that such blows rain down in vengeance!
121 The leader then asked him who he was; 122 to which he replied: "I fell from Tuscany, 123 a short time ago, into this fierce pit.
**Old English:**
119 Ea, Godes miht, hu micel hit is, 120 ðæt swylce witu for wraðe cymð!
121 Þa ðone heretoga ða æfter frægn, 122 hwæt he wære oððe hwanan he come; 123 he ða andswarode and ðus cwæð: "Ic feoll of Tuscia, 124 lyt hwile is, on ðisne deopan dal.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
124 Vita bestial mi piacque e non umana, 125 sì come a mul ch’i’ fui; son Vanni Fucci 126 bestia, e Pistoia mi fu degna tana».
query.result:
**English:**
124 Bestial life pleased me and not human, 125 just like a mule that I was; I am Vanni Fucci, 126 a beast, and Pistoia was my worthy den.
**Old English:**
124 Deorlifes me licode and na mannes, 125 swa swa mule ðe ic wæs; ic eom Vanni Fucci, 126 deor, and Pistoia wæs min wyrðe den.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
127 E ïo al duca: «Dilli che non mucci, 128 e domanda che colpa qua giù ’l pinse; 129 ch’io ’l vidi uomo di sangue e di crucci».
query.result:
**English:**
127 And I to the leader: "Tell him not to be silent, 128 and ask what fault thrust him down here; 129 for I saw him as a man of blood and strife."
**Old English:**
127 And ic ðam heretogan: "Saga ðæt he ne swige, 128 and bidde hine hwæt synna hine hider onsende; 129 ðæt ic hine geseah for blódigne man and for grimne."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
136 Io non posso negar quel che tu chiedi; 137 in giù son messo tanto perch’ io fui 138 ladro a la sagrestia d’i belli arredi,
139 e falsamente già fu apposto altrui.
query.result:
**English:**
136 I cannot deny what you ask; 137 I am placed down here because I was 138 a thief of the sacristy of the beautiful furnishings,
139 and falsely it was once attributed to another.
**Old English:**
136 Ne mæg ic ðæt forswarian ðæt ðu secge, 137 niðer ic eom on þisne stede gesett forðæm ic wæs 138 sceapa on ðære halgan stowe ðara fægeran fata,
139 and lease me wæs ðæt onleget.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
140 Ma perché di tal vista tu non godi, 141 se mai sarai di fuor da’ luoghi bui,
142 apri li orecchi al mio annunzio, e odi.
query.result:
**English:**
140 But why do you not rejoice at such a sight, 141 if ever you shall be outside of the dark places,
142 open your ears to my message, and listen.
**Old English:**
140 Ac hwi ne ongietst ðu ðære gesyhðe, 141 gif ðu æfre ðonne becomst of ðam dimman stowum,
142 ontyne ðine earen to minum bodscipe, and gehyr.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
151 E detto l’ho perché doler ti debbia!».
query.result:
**English:**
151 And I said this so that you may grieve!
**Old English:**
151 And ic ðæt sæde ðæt ðu ðe sceolde gehreowan!
